review_title: Hired  30+ years ago and never left.....
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: Excellent medical and vacation benefits, very close knit staff that work together at every level to get the job done, high level of compassion for our customers - our patients, very diverse cultural population amongst the staff and an environment where career advancement is encouraged and fostered.  I myself have worked my way up professionally over the last three decades.  I know first hand that management's first concern is to offer people at their most vulnerable times during illness and pain the most compassionate, quality care that is available.  I have not only been a long time employee but a patient both inpatient and outpatient and receive all my medical care at Beth Israel.
cons: None that I have experienced.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Great research environment and facilities. You get to work with very intelligent colleagues and you are encouraged to collaborate. There is a robust publishing record in academic journals. This may, of course, be department specific.

You are encouraged to conduct research that is directly relevant to the clinic.
cons: Long hours and low pay is what comes with the territory when you do postdoc research. This is not unique to Mount Sinai School of Medicine.

job_title: Practice Administrator in Chicago, IL
pros: It's a good location, you can access the medical center easily via Union Square.  The benefits package is not bad.
cons: Very disorganized. I joined the team shortly before the hospital went under Mt Sinai.  I was discouraged and thought I had made s mistake taking the job knowing that I would have to stay at least a year before changing positions. When the new President Susan Somerville came I was hopeful. But in no time it was easy to see that she and her leadership team were in over their heads. At first the changes were great but all progress has stopped and the new team is very dismissive of anyone who is not new.  There are employees there that have great ideas and can help move along the medical center to improve but if the ideas do not one from Susan's people no one listens.

review_title: Do they stand up to their name?!?!
job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Pension and health care plan. At Roosevelt, the nurses don’t clock in.
cons: Use to be Good PTO. They took a lot away. Depends with hospital. Beth Israel have rumors of closing. Roosevelt can’t seem to make up their minds about a name. Mount Sinai Hospital have black out days for vacations. Beware. Seniority Seniority Seniority! All I can say. You might not get that vacation.

job_title: IT Analyst III in New York, NY
pros:
Good pay, good benefits, good for your resume.
Level of coworkers is very good. There is diversity in employees.
cons:
Morale is low, no career perspective. In this work environment you can see that everybody is in survival mode. People work in silos. Management does not promote teamwork.
No privacy at all. Even meeting rooms and senior management offices have glass walls.
Older employees get discriminated. 
A serious problem at higher management is very weak financial planning. Meaning that projects get scuttled because budgets were cut after 2 months. People get laid off.
Very frugal on what they provide to employees. You have to get your traveling expenses pre-approved, don't expect that just because it was a traveling expense you will get reimbursed.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in New York, NY
pros: Having the experience on your resume
cons: Eat their young, not very friendly atmosphere on some units, staff not welcoming to new employees,  young preceptors not helpful. There is a dark underside to this company that some are lucky to avoid (usually those on the lighter side of things).

review_title: Great atmosphere, culture, and the benefits include 29 Paid Days off, but the salaries are below market.
job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: This all depends on which Department you work in but there are lots of good people to work for and with. The paid time off is easily the best benefit. Most workers work a straight 9-5 and leave right at 5. Central Park is across the street when you can get out for lunch in the warmer weather.
cons: Again this depends on the department, but salaries are notoriously low and it is a hassle to get a raise or promotion. HR takes a very long time and also during the hiring process.

job_title: Senior Buyer in New York, NY
pros: Good place to be a senior clinician or researcher, terrible place to be support staff
cons: The acquisition last year of Continuum Health more than doubled Mount Sinai's size. Support staff are being reassigned apparently at random with no choice and little direction from management. At a recent staff meeting, people were told Plan D for merging the two systems was being implemented, since Plans A through C had proved unworkable. Management makes apparently arbitrary decisions with no regard for employee wishes or the impact changes will have on them. There is no work-life balance. Work is all there is. Politics runs rampant. It has become a very uncomfortable place to work.

job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Location, family work enviornment staff dedication, health benefits, pension, education
cons: THE NEW PRESIDENT....her main goal is for everything to be outpatient basis. Staff are terrified for their jobs every waking moment. plus Ms. Sommerville lacks operational and strategic skills to led BIMC away from serious financial difficulties, which other qualified presidents for Mt. Sinai hospitals have proven to successfully do, Sommervilles goal is to attempt to make more than half of health care on an out patient basis....yes that saves money.....guess she didn't factor in med non compliance....and a multitude of situations that need continuous 24 hour monitoring and observation.

job_title: Laboratory Service Representative in New York, NY
pros: Officially part of the 1199 SEIU, Benefits, depending on job (good environment), if there was more
cons:
Alienation of employees (by other employees or even Supervisors), some or most hire-up are not personally involved with their staff and if they are it's mostly out of picking favorites or comfortability factor, Not much of a good environment to get along with people, Tough learning curve, Hard to get promoted from within, mostly everything you do even little things are often critiqued, hate working weekends.

Possible placement of lithium in the water supply which is why I avoid drinking from their fountains.

review_title: It's ok as a entry-way if you have no degree
job_title: Nutrition Aide in New York, NY
pros:
1- most willing to work a little with schedule, but mention it only After your three-month probation.
2- Just don't be super late or absent, and articulate yourself like this is a stepping stone. Mount Sinai needs more forward thinkers, more readers.
3- union does help you after a YEAR of being there (education, vacation benefits)
cons:
1- you may have no break some days
2- you may not always have overtime
3- you have to play some politics with bosses and coworkers-- not everyone is nice without you helping them on 1-2 things
4- all hospital food service is outsourced to a management company, be very nice to them and they won't mess with you.

review_title: Good company but showing break down in employees.
job_title: EMR Credentialed Trainer in Meridian, ID
pros:
Always pay on time.
Good wages
Friendly Staff
cons:
Benefits aren't great. Family of four cost me $550.
Lately, I have watched many long term employees promised (literally) they would keep a job and now told they're time is up in a few months.
I was also told my time was coming to an end soon due to cut backs. I interviewed for a position I was well qualified for only to be told I was second in line and they hired someone externally.

review_title: Beth Israel Medical Center requires hard work and dedication from its employees.
job_title: Staff RN in New York, NY
pros: There is a great opportunity for advancement, as Continuum is a huge group of hospitals in New York City. Specifically, Beth Israel Medical Center belongs to a strong union: 1199, and it's delegates will fight for the union members right as much as it takes. Unlike most hospitals where there is a limit on tuition reimbursement, Continuum offers 100% reimbursement of health-care related tuition fees.
cons:
Beth Israel Medical Center is one of the lowest paying hospital in terms of salaries in NYC.
Vacations / personal days are based on seniority. None of the Continuum hospitals are  magnet designated. Also, most patients in Beth Israel are on medicare/medicaid, which does not give the facility financial stability.

review_title: Poor management, bad research infrastructure, exploitative insurance packages
job_title: Research Coordinator in New York, NY
pros:
- Salary is marginally more than other similar positions in NYC (lower than Rockefeller, higher than Langone)
- Nothing else
cons:
- Terrible benefits program. On the surface, the rates/coverage seem okay but actually dealing with the ADP benefits staff is incredibly frustrating.  Many of my co-workers and I have horror stories of just losing lots of money or spending hours settling bills. (I have the non-union benefits program, so I cannot speak for the union based ones)
- This probably depends on your department,  but mine was a mess. No clear sense of who is in charge of a particular responsibility because of the sharp disjunction between clinical/scientific staff and admin.
- You have to submit to a pre-employment toxicology screen. 
- Shady financial ties (see: Carl Icahn)

review_title: Good pay and benefits, at the cost of burnout and bad management
job_title: Registered Nurse, Critical Care in New York, NY
pros: Amazing coworkers and decent relationships with docs I worked with.  Excellent pay and benefits. A shoutout to the staff I worked with who did the best for our patients despite our circumstances.
cons: Incredibly unsafe staffing, 24 hour shifts needed to keep unit a float, as well as staying late consistently.  Management disregarded suggestions for staffing issues from nursing staff. Not enough resources, despite being a top institution in NYC.  For me, not worth the pay and benefits any longer.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Grand opportunity to work alongside top doctors and academic professors. Wonderful graduate school program.
cons: Lack of transparency. Lack of effective communication from the top down. Low pay. Lack of community within the workplace environment and departments. Lack of career development mentoring and opportunities for non-MD personnel . HR is not effective towards helping employees in good standing move forward in career trajectory and development.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros:
- In Manhattan
- They do provide subsidized housing for 3 years close to Sinai (rent is high but it's lower than average for the area- some buildings are better than others)
- Looks good on your CV
- Can be good research environment but heavily dependent on PI (Sinai puts tremendous pressure on the PIs to perform and bring in money and this pressure gets put directly onto postdocs)
cons:
- Severe mistreatment of postdocs
- Very difficult to get promoted (the longer you stay, the greater the chance- which results in really bad people getting promoted)
- The only thing they care about is money- people don't matter
- The mental health of employees is poor and Mount Sinai does whatever it can to hide that fact.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Good health care and vacation benefits. Lots of new alternative job opportunities. Generally good atmosphere. Excellent free training opportunities in personal development conflict solutions etc. Very good Employee Assistance Program.
cons: ItÂ´s a huge hospital, so I canÂ´t generalize, but in my unit there were severe internal conflicts, competition, disorganization and lack of communication with other clinics and programs. The hospital is too focused on making money and too little interested in taking care of clients. But this is the American system.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits. 20 days vacation from day and exceptional health care coverage. Direct managers for the most part genuinely care about their employees. Seems to be a place to make a career if you can take or are insulated from the backstabbing and politics.
cons: Unless you are a political animal and are willing to step on others to get a ahead, you will merely survive at Sinai. Senior management (C-level) will make disparaging remarks about other employees and will openly berate employees in meetings.

job_title: Social Worker in New York, NY
pros:
Large and growing social work department. 
Interesting opportunities such as attending conferences 
Tuition reimbursement $2,300
Decent health benefits but cost increases every year 
good SW clinical experience
Ability to obtain hours for LCSW
Can work with limited permit until LMSW is obtained
cons:
If you look closely, institutional racism runs deeps.
Outpatient social workers are mostly all of color and when jobs postings list "preferred spanish speaking."
Most inpatient specialities med surg,etc are social workers who look a specific way. (not POC)
No room for growth, the new incoming SW program coordinators are White and non spanish speaking and not promoted from within.  
Little room for growth or promotion.
Lack of support for program coordinators

job_title: Tech in New York, NY
pros: The benefits for the employees e.g. Wellness programs and the employee discounts.
cons:
Management needs to be more aware of their workers and what goes on in their respective departments.

Some problems and issues drag on too long before being solved or taken care of.

Listen to the employees, they have a voice to and should be heard

Staff need to work together and stop trying to outdo each other at times

Some staff needs to stop hiding behind the union.

job_title: Medical/Administrative in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Place is clean and appears new. Most  medical staff is competent and friendly.
cons: Urgent  Care and secretarial staff is terribly run-especially during the weekend. Pediatric floor is unclean. Procedure room on 18th floor is unclean and needs better supervision. Too many employees engaging in unprofessional conversations concerning race, gender issues, employees and excessive cell phone use-especially in Pediatrics, Urgent Care and front desk. Low performance and incompetency. Lack  of HR representation. No offered employee training or incentives. Lack of educated or experienced skilled Management.

job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: Mount Sinai School of Medicine may be good for technicians, administration staff and housekeepers. Although these jobs are paid not high, they are not challenging, so these people are relaxed and have a good life. It is also good for nurses who are paid very well. It is the best the place for doctors with MD degree, who are given the best respect, opportunities, promotion, high pay, and other benefits.
cons: Depending on what types of jobs. As a scientist with a PhD degree, it is very difficult to thrive because they are NOT given chances and supports to succeed. They are just tools for MD to succeed.

job_title: Physician in New York, NY
pros: Hardworking employees !  Good retirement savings package!
cons: Administration is not willing to spend funds to improve work flow.  The computers and software are way outdated and inefficient and constantly do not work properly. Place is filthy - not enough cleaning staff to keep the place clean (dust everywhere outside of patient care areas). Not enough patient care aides for the patients - so patients are constantly waiting for staff if they need manual assistance for any reason (walking to bath room or repositioning, etc). Not enough clerks to answer the phones! All these little issues add up to a very inefficient day for every employee who works there and a hospital run in this manner cannot keep patients satisfied and be very profitable.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros:
One if the big advantages working at Mount Sinai Hospital is to have the privilege to work and collaborate with leading clinician scientist and to get access to precious patient samples.  
Also Mount Sinai offers affordable housing for postdoctoral fellows for 3 years that makes living in this expensive city possible.
cons: A big disadvantage of working as a postdoctoral fellow at Mount Sinai Hospital is that maternity leave for postdocs is only 2 month and daycare expenses for babies and children in New York City are very expensive incompatible  with the postdoc salary.

review_title: Mount Sinai School of Medicine is cool~
job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: Located at the upper east side of Manhattan, it's only 5 mins walk from the central park. One of the best hospitals nation wide. The faculty generally are high profile and respectful. It's an up and coming institute which is gaining more and more recognition. The hospital also has very nice facilities.
cons: The administration at the school of medicine is close to horrible. The supporting staffs seem to be indifferent and do not care about faculty's needs. There are also quite a bit of politics among faculty members.

job_title: Radiologic Technologist in New York, NY
pros: Mount Sinai is a learning hospital so I feel they are a little bit more lenient towards new graduates. The environment is pretty friendly well within the departments and there is opportunity to learn within the hospital. You can start in the diagnostic field and branch off. If you are ambitious you can go places.
cons: Because they are willing to hire people straight out of school, they seem to have a high turnover. It seems like the philosophy is " If you don't like it leave because you can be replaced". I have not personally seen this but it's the underlying tone. Also even though the opportunity for growth is there the finincial compensation is not quite there yet.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Mount Sinai, NY
pros: Learned to be more assertive, decent union benefits such as continuing education and slight pay increases, offered overtime but rare
cons: Micromanagement, supervisor yelling, low morale, paranoia between coworkers, bullying, discouragement from climbing career ladder, racial discrimination, high turnover, working with homeless population

job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits, lots of PTO, professional growth and development classes and resources for employees, and the stability of working for a large organization
cons: Despite what they say about wanting to keep talent in-house, haven't found talent development, HR or my own department particularly helpful in trying to move to better opportunities in the system. It can be hard to navigate and feel kind of silo'd at times, and they don't  pay as much as other institutions for healthcare PM roles

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, competitive salary, upward mobility
cons: Understaffed and unclear job description. Actually, the job description was clear, but the daily tasks were not what I signed up for. Also, outdated technology and a lot of jaded, dead-weight staff. Really depressing-looking office that I don't think has been renovated since the 80s.

job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY

cons: Management is so out of touch with the day to day responsibilities of IT and the amount of personnel it takes to successfully complete projects. Lately It’s all about metrics and meetings. You all have really lost sight of who is getting work done during the day.

review_title: Good and safe workplace but not easy to transfer between departments
job_title: Scheduler in New York, NY
pros: Fair salary, good benefits and safe workplace.
cons: Recruitment process is very time consuming. On the contrary to an official statement it's not easy to transfer to a different administrative position via internal job postings , even if it's equal in pay and job description, so it means that you might be stuck in the same job, even when you feel it's time to move. On the other side their HR is very helpful in case of layoffs and really tries to keep you in the company.

review_title: Don't walk, run! Run for your life!
job_title: Practice Manager in New York, NY
pros: Decent Pay. Easy Commute from the Subway.
cons: Terrible management. Out of touch with the rest of the staff. Physicians have no respect for their staff. As managers, we have no control over absolutely anything, but are constantly blamed for everything. Trust me, this place is going down in flames. Even with the recent merger of Mount Sinai, they are still going nowhere. Money is being shoveled out the door every day on wasteful projects and fat-cat physicians who do little/no work. Everyone is trying to get out of here. Everyone (and I mean everyone) is trying to leave.

review_title: Mount Sinai is a promising institution, salary negotiation is difficult

job_title: Medical Assistant in New York, NY

job_title: Program Coordinator in Bronx, NY

cons: Tons of paperwork, but you should be fine if you manage your time wisely. Also, begin working on your calendars early in the month, this will make your data entry at the end of the month much easier.

job_title: Project Coordinator II in New York, NY
pros: This was my first job out of university. I had no real professional experience in a corporate environment coming in. I'm thankful for the opportunities I was given to grow and the freedom to work with people and teams across the system.
cons: There was no mentorship or training involved during onboarding. Everything I learned in my job was learned through mistakes made due to a lack of communication of proper protocol. I had no team to split work amongst and was often called upon to complete tasks that other more experienced colleagues were not capable of doing or did not want to do. Relationship with supervisor was extremely toxic and was frequently spoken down to, belittled, and had unrealistic expectations set of me. I was asked to complete tasks that challenged my own personal ethics. I was held accountable for tasks that were not under my own personal control and constantly stressed because of a feeling of failure and inability to satisfy the unrealistic expectations I was held to. Turnover rate in the department is extremely high and despite my relatively short tenure here, I have seen dozens of my colleagues released from their positions. Many of the colleagues that are still here and in other departments echo my sentiments and we are all operating at the bare minimum level of productivity as a result of lack of resources, poor managerial oversight, high pressure environment, and achievable expectations that cause high levels of employee burnout and dissatisfaction.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Progressive culture. As an Associate Professor (Tenure track), my salary is 30% paid by the department, and 70% paid by grants. Thus there is considerable pressure to get grants to maintain my job. My department also offers a bonus scheme based on (Federal) grant income. Basically once most of your salary is covered by grants, you will get ~5% of the direct costs of your annual Federal grants back as bonus each year. So, if you bring in $1M in NIH grants, you get a $50k bonus.
cons: There is considerable pressure to get grants to maintain my job

review_title: My overall experience was ok working in the hospital

review_title: Come here if you want to become a doctor, or a medical researcher.

review_title: Way too much bureaucracy and not enough consideration for the non-clinical laboratory side
job_title: Research Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Depending on where you work, the view of the city is amazing, especially sunsets over Central Park.
cons:
There is way too much bureaucracy here-- my entire research lab moved here from another institution and we all had to "apply" for our jobs, including supplying references.  I guess I can understand the health check and drug testing, but it just seemed like they needed to "check off the box" with the entire "application" process.  

In addition, the new employee orientation was very much geared towards people who work on the clinical side.  I've never understood why strictly non-clinical research staff need to go through such thorough training related to HIPAA guidelines when we have no access to patient information, but I assume there is a legal requirement for anyone working in a hospital system (or maybe I did somehow have access?!).  Anyway, while we had to sit through a whole bunch of irrelevant training, the lab-specific information that would have been extremely useful was never discussed.  I realize that I was in a relatively unique situation in that my entire lab was new to the institution and its procedures, but it would probably be a good idea for all new lab employees to be told, for example, how to properly dispose of toxic chemicals.  That way no one could ever claim ignorance because no one told them.

Finally, I felt a real lack of community on the non-clinical side.  At other institutions I've worked at, there have been frequent seminars that allow employees to see each other in a more relaxed setting.  And of course, weekly happy hours can foster a sense of community that goes beyond socializing and can help spark new research avenues and collaborations between labs.

job_title: Research Coordinator in New York, NY

The hardworking employees get no recognition and the lazy employees do not receive any disciplinary action.  Eventually the hardworking employees leave or give up.

job_title: in Secaucus, NJ

There are way too many to list. Most lower and upper management needs to be replaced with professionals. Inconsistent policies and managerial contradictions. Under staffed, overworked and underpaid.

review_title: Not for a junior faculty Physician Scientist with a family.
job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: Great coworkers. Greatest city in the world. Institution carries a good reputation. Grant support for NIH submission. Large patient population.
cons: Salary is not commensurate with living in NYC. Resources given to junior faculty are minimal. Start up funding and protected time are poor. Not a real commitment to career development. Still about the almighty dollar, ie billing. What was supposed to be an 80% research 20% clinical became the reverse because of the need to bill. This option was presented with threats of being fired if you did not comply. Other colleagues look defeated and just accepting of their fate.

review_title: Read This and You'll Never Want to Work for Mount Sinai Hospital
job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Norwalk, CT
pros: There's a La Quotidien and Dunkin Donuts just across the street, which is important because the hospital is in East Harlem and you won't want to venture more than a block or two in any direction.
cons:
They put me through a rigorous screening and onboarding process that took 4 months.  Then when they hired me, they reneged on a verbal commitment to reimburse me $2,500 for moving expenses, citing a "change in  policy" (during the protracted onboarding process).  I hemorrhaged a lot of cash due to these factors.  Then they let me go after 3.5 months simply because a new doctor they on-boarded 2 days after me thought a former associate (who was also a good friend, AKA crony) would be better in my position. (Both the new doctor and his friend were over 70 years old and came out of retirement to join Sinai).  I had just signed a lease!  The doctors couldn't even deliver the news personally.  They had HR do it.  And citing policy again, because the termination occurred during the probationary period, they could not make themselves available to me for a reference. I thought the timing of the termination was a bit suspicious but then I learned they fired me 3 days before I qualified for unemployment benefits.  They were in the middle of a hiring binge and had hired about 100 new staff a week for the past year, so I suspect this is a racket where Sinai casually hires a lot of people and uses their probationary mechanism to let many of them go and just before they qualify for unemployment. (This way Sinai avoids increases in their unemployment insurance rate).  So I was happy I left with some of the documents I was working on or else I'd have nothing to show for my time there, but then I began receiving threatening emails from the Chief Counsel at the behest of the doctors and the Compliance officers, claiming Sinai and only Sinai are the rightful owners of anything I produced there.  The threats included the New York State police and the Department of Justice.  (If you so a web search on Sinai legal activities, you'll find evidence that they like to resort to aggressive scorched-earth tactics.  Fortunately Judge Bermann did not allow them to use such tactics to quash a qui tam whistle-blower lawsuit that has been filed against them on behalf of staff claiming the hospital is engaged in Medicare fraud).  If that weren't enough, they neglected to send me my W-2.  And while I was there, they never gave me a dedicated workstation.  No office.  No cube.  They eventually got me an inadequate laptop (though I had no place to sit with it except the floor) and no means to print documents.  They let me use one of the primitive PCs that are reserved for monitors, and they kicked me off the PC whenever a monitor needed it.  The administrator in charge of delegating these resources yelled at me during our introductory meeting, claiming the doctors who hired me never informed her I was in their plans.  I was told that for that reason, I would never be given a proper workstation. 

The hospital is very invasive and sanctimonious.  They expect nothing but excellence from their employees, which is astonishing considering all the substandard work I witnessed while I was there.  And the hospital is always threatening to invade your bloodstream.  The pre-employment drug screen was not enough.  They like to herd employees into what they call the 8-hour annual health assessment, a comprehensive physical.  And you never know exactly when it's coming.  They also like to taut their policy of random drug testing.  And based on the EPIC data dumps I reviewed, they're always drug testing their cancer patients.

job_title: Clinical Research Intern in New York, NY
pros: Strong academic prestige that facilitates learning opportunities.
cons: Nepotism played a huge part in whom learned certain things and whom did not. These decisions were solely based on research assistants just "liking" an intern based on looks and appearances without actually speaking to him/her. I actually reported this to a Principal Investigator who actually tried to spin it around and tried to frame the blame on me, and actually informed the people who I reported that I reported them. Completely violated the confidential policy.

review_title: The worst medical records coding management team ever.
job_title: Medical Records Coding Professional in New York, NY
pros: Great location, great reputation as a Medical Center.  One of the best hospitals in NY.  Wonderful diversity and work staff.
cons:
Mount Sinai is a wonderful hospital on the cutting edge of technology and care.  As a professional Medical Records Coder I was more than excited to start my new job there.  Unfortunately from day one I experienced the worst possible treatment and total lack of respect from the team of managers who just the week before was so thrilled to "welcome me on board."  The supervisor who I had to report directly had no formal ICD-9 or CPT training or credentials whatsoever.  Coders and staff could not go to her for any questions on actual coding issues, yet they HAD to.  The big "rule" of the department was that no coding communication of any sort was allowed between CRMs and staff without her explicit approval on a case by case basis. Imagine this in a busy coding office! This was the biggest frustration I had to deal with.   Twice I found myself called into the office for having an "improper communication with a coder."  By the second week of employment I had enough and moved on elsewhere to a much more open, professional, and rewarding job at a much less prestigious hospital.
The coding managers at Mount Sinai are, unfortunately, very much dedicated to micro-managing and controlling the behavior of its staff and in the process, completely demeaning and demoralizing them terribly.  They focus on so many rules, and processes, and functions, and forming graphs and charts and holding countless, wasteful meetings where nothing productive is ever accomplished.  It is unfortunate because the case mix at this hospital is an amazing challenge and training tool for any coder. It would be a great place to work if it wasn't for this very dysfunctional group of control freaks who are in charge.  The coding staff -- who are union, probably the only reason they stay -- deserve great kudos for what they have to put up with and for doing such good work.  If anything gets done in this department it is because the coding staff lives up to some very arbitrary rules and impossible standards.  If you do plan on accepting a job at Mount Sinai, be prepared for a hasty exit.  Run don't walk.

review_title: My experience at Mount Sinai is one of complete disappointment.
job_title: Medical Records in New York, NY
pros: Mount Sinai has to be given Kudos for attempting to create an atmosphere of mutual respect.  They have implemented The BEST and AIDET initiative programs.  They have the employees assistance program and provide opportunities for the employees to further their education.
cons: The problems begins when these same programs are turned on the employee and used to hurt them instead of help.  When LEM goals become ridiculously impossible and laughable.  Basically, you feel that your being set up ot fail.  AIDET, although, should be done as a professional courtesy becomes mandatory.  Although, anonymous as well, you must fill out a special form and name detailed incidents of colleagues bad behavior.  This is the twisted and distorted programs that exist now.  Then you are told that it counts for 50% of your yearly review.  Oh yeah, and no one qualifies for the "E"s. Everyone gets an "M" or "N" .  No one can possibly exceed the standard of Mount Sinai.  The demoralizing and demeaning way we are treated is incomprehensible.  We stay because we pray it will get better.  This month we are losing some people.  The job satisfaction is gone and the self-respect has to take over sometime. The culture of Micromangement from the top down is enough to make you sick to your stomach.  This is the mental and distorted mind of middle management.

review_title: Senior management of MSMC needs to take the blinders off and see what is really going on !!
job_title: Medical Records in New York, NY
pros:
1) One of the best hospitals in the world.
2) Recruits top notch physicians to care for simple to complex disease and treatment.  A hospital that can care for any disease and it's treatment.
3) Easily reached via subway, car.
4) Staff really tries to take care of the patient.  They work on professionalism, friendliness and concern for the patient. 
5) Security is good.  
6) They are working on cleanliness.
7) One of the best hospital cafeterias around; a bit pricey but the food doesn't look like baked Alpo.
cons:
1) Management ( or micro-management )  thrives on terrorizing the employees; many are leaving.  People who were there for years are leaving due to the abuse and demeaning atmosphere.  Their opinions and concerns are not deemed worthy; most of all their experience means nothing.  The senior management and middle management have serious issues with confrontation; suggestions, issues are not heard.  Work should not be a trial in dealing with psychosis.  
2) Unreasonable work loads.  Management thinks nothing of adding additional duties making it impossible to finish your work load. How can you learn, be promoted or hope to continue employment when you are constantly loaded with duties and harassed on top of it?  You are set up to fail rather than succeed.  That's what the management wants; for you to fail and get fired for not completing your required work load.  If you are smart; you will leave before that happens.
3) Departmental meetings were long ago discontinued; management probably got tired of hearing the issues at hand.  They can't deal with issues; so why have a departmental meeting ??   
4) The consultants are taking over in some areas; many of whom don't know what they are doing.

job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: There is nothing positive about being in a Non Union position. Union position is far superior with the great benefits, job security, and the sick time. If you want to advance your career, this is not the place to do it since you would need to leave the Union. Non Union is great if you want a title but you'll need to pay dearly for your medical/ dental benefits with expensive copayments, no job security and with no pension. This is a no brainier but to stay content in an Union position. So, if you're ambitious, this hospital will now be suited for you because you would need to leave the Union.
cons: If you are motivated to climb the career ladder, this is not the place to do it. Why? It means you would need to leave a Union position giving up the outstanding medical/dental benefits, a pension, job security, child care fund, etc...I left the Union and got a managerial position thinking it was best for my career.  I was wrong and regret it ever since. As a non Union employee, I pay substantially more for my medical/dental benefits. There is no job security whatsoever. Also, my net amount on my check now is actually less due to the cost of benefits despite the increase in salary. Union position is the way to go if you stay here. You can always make up the salary descrepancy by getting a side job... The benefits in the Union are too great to give up... Trust me...

review_title: No structure, managers and supervisors ignorant to daily processes.

pros: After years working at this organization throughout its many changes and take overs I can't find anything good to say about the experiences here. cons: Over worked, unrecognized for any and all efforts. Constant regime changes with new or inexperienced managers who come along looking to make a name for themselves - destroying what little good is working within the departments they supervise. The job descriptions are not inclusive of the work being asked. Administrative positions are in most cases patient care based. You sign on ready to support a division and find yourself doing multiple things you were never told at the time of your interview. You will do authorizations for meds, procedures and also wind up being held responsible for multiple other people's mistakes while the people truly responsible make excuses and point fingers. Managers and supervisors are divisive and look to cause friction between coworkers. Most of these managers who could or should pitch in sit back and delegate everything onto the next guy and take credit for any and all progress made. They promote their own within this organization and others hire people with no experience and expect the employees to train new staff while being burdened with an already overwhelming work load. Depending on your manager Mt Sinai can be an amazing rewarding experience or an absolute nightmare. I transferred to Sinai Heart from clinic and I absolutely regret my decision. I got the manager from hell. When I LEFT Sinai, she tried to burn me at my new position at Presbyterian! I got sick during my last two weeks [after I resigned] and she tried to make me call sick from my current job to "make up" the days to her like I was some slave!!!

There are some units that NEVER receive transfer applicants, it's for a reason! You didn't land some amazing opportunity, you got a job no one else wanted! They know better! And while they'll take you without completing your year requirement, they don't let you go until you've completed a year and then they write false things on your record so you can't transfer or talk ill about you to the manager looking to hire you. DO NOT TOUCH MOUNT SINAI HEART. 

Some units in Sinai have 5-12 patients per assignment for PCA. NOT MOUNT SINAI HEART. You can have 12-36 patients! Operating room prep! EKG! Blood work! Weight! ADLs. And more and more patients require total care. You often have to cut your break short to make sure everything gets done. Sinai Heart has excess work that other units don't have ALL WHILE BEING DANGEROUSLY UNDERSTAFFED! NYSNA is saying they need safe patient ratios! The auxilliary staff do too! Often you have no support because you're overwhelmed with the work. I'm so happy I left! Such abuse, both from management and lateral. 

Do not touch Mount Sinai Heart! Not as your first job within the health system. They will trap you there.

job_title: Patient Care Associate in New York, NY

The benefits are very good. 
There is an opportunity to move around if you are unhappy in your current position.
The managers are often open to work with your schedule.
It is a learning hospital.
cons: Hospital is still changing many things since Mount Sinai took over. It could get a little frustrating to keep up with so many changes.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY

Also, they constantly try to push other roles onto you with no raise and isn't even part of your job description.

job_title: Management in New York, NY

job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY

job_title: Cook in Bronx, NY

you learn a great deal of preparing differents kinds of food and learn the safety ways of doing so
and also learn a great way to be a team player
cons: if not careful you will get hurt if you dont follow directrions or hurt someone if not careful

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY

job_title: Executive Assistant in New York, NY

review_title: Mount Sinai hospital is the last place you want to work in.

Unqualified managers working at St. Luke's Lab with a high school diploma and no experience.
Lab Director only promotes her friends no matter how rude or unqualified they are.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in New York, NY

review_title: Great opportunities for new-grad and experienced nurses.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
